text:
a lot of people know of Nasdaq for the equities 
exchange that we run in in New York but Nasdaq

actually does quite a bit more than that Nasdaq 
is a technology and services provider to over

120 different exchanges regulators post trade 
entities in more than 50 countries worldwide

Nasdaq loads between 30 and 60 billion records 
every night and once we've loaded that data we

have to run our billing and reporting and some 
other processing against that data prior to the

market opening the next day as that volume 
increased it became more and more difficult

to fit the loading process as well as the the 
billing and reporting querying processes into

that you know 12-hour window effectively between 
6:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. we embarked on a project

to migrate to a data like solution we moved 
that ingest process into AWS entirely just

writing the data into Amazon s3 so the first 
objective was really to to scale and improve

the speed at which we were able to load data in 
and then the second objective was to choose a

query architecture that would allow us to query 
that data in a much more parallel manner where

there wasn't as much contention between multiple 
different functions querying that data at the same

time now that we've migrated our billing 
processes to run off of redshift spectrum

the performance gains that we're seeing are 
significant on average I think that our our

performance against redshift spectrum is about 
66 60 to 65% faster than it was against redshift

itself we have some processes that are as much as 
90 percent faster we have one billing process that

went from taking about 40 minutes to now running 
at four minutes and one thing that I would do

differently if we were doing this project again 
would be to incorporate the AWS data lab into the

project plan itself I wish that we hadn't waited 
so late in the project to take advantage of that

service we came out of that week at AWS data 
lab with answers in a clear path to how we were

going to solve the problems that we were that 
we were facing it is something that is kind of

part of the the AWS culture that they're always 
trying to help us find ways to improve things
